[b]My playtime:[/b] 73.8h (based on steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~3 achievements).
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~29 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~2 achievements).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[i]Crashlands[/i] is a game where you have to gather resources, kill enemies, and craft items to defeat bosses.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 4 difficulties
- 3 game modes
- Unique bosses
- You can finish quests in any order that you want
- A lot of craftable items, including the ones used for decoration purposes
- Pets with different abilities

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Gear crafting is luck-based
- Sometimes the game might feel too grindy
- Too many gadgets and devices to choose from
- Hardcore mode beats the point of the game
- You need to wait for minutes to craft or hours to wait for a resource to respawn
- Auto-lock tends to lose target

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like games where you have to gather resources, kill enemies, and craft things, this is your game. The game has some difficult achievements in the hardcore mode though so you might want to reconsider if you aim for 100% completion.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The designs are simple and clean. Most enemies are cute-looking and everything looks comical. I also liked the pet evolution screen that looked like [i]Pokémon[/i], although it's executed differently.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game has a unique storytelling. Instead of taking everything seriously, everyone talks nonchalantly and jokes around - even to the final boss. There were times when I had to reread the conversation twice though; sometimes it's kinda hard to get what they were talking about.

[h1]The game[/h1]
[b]Modes[/b]
The game has 3 game modes: story, hardcore, and creative. Story mode is the standard game where you will get an actual story and quests. Both hardcore and creative mode will be unlocked after you reach a certain point in the story mode.

Hardcore, on the other hand, is a story mode without quests and extra life. Yes, you have to restart the game if you accidentally die from an enemy. Since there is no story in this mode, I found that the recipe gathering took too much time. The perma-death also made the mode to be frustrating; it seems that it beats the purpose of the game where you have to take your time to craft the ultimate gear and explore the map.

Creative mode isn't an actual game. It's more dedicated to those who want to get... creative. You have unlimited resources and no objective. You can either build your dream home base or draw something from the floor tiles or... anything.

[b]Exploration[/b]
The game focuses on resource-gathering and exploration. You'll be thrown in a land, gather some resources, and craft new items from the said resources. The game has a very vast map and it's almost impossible to uncover everything. I was even surprised that the game ran smoothly even though I had revealed a lot of portion of the map; it only took longer to wait when I opened a map or traveled to a different land.

The game has 3 lands to explore. Each land has a unique theme, quests, crafted items - everything. It's as if you're playing the same game 3 different times before you finished the actual game.

[b]Crafting[/b]
You can craft pieces of equipment, tools to gather better resources, and even decoration items that serve no purpose except to make your base looks better. Crafting becomes vital in the game if you want to do almost anything because you can only obtain most items by crafting.

Although you can craft some items at the start, some items require a recipe to craft. In story mode, these recipes are dropped either from gathering resources, killing enemies or bosses, or completing quests. You will have all recipes from the start in creative mode and you can get the recipes from all but the latter in hardcore mode.

Crafting takes time. There are some items where you have to wait for a few minutes to craft. I felt like I was playing a Facebook game because of this. Luckily, you don't need to wait that long in hardcore mode and you can also do other things while you wait.

[b]Resource Gathering[/b]
Resource gathering takes time, especially if you don't know where to look for an item. The game might have a feature to track how many items that you need, but the game fails to tell you where you can get the said item. Even if you know where to get it, it might still take some time to gather since some items are not common in the land. There are even some resources that take hours to respawn.

[b]Battles[/b]
Apart from resources that you can pick up, there are times where you have to battle enemies to gather resources. Some enemies are easy to beat, some might kill you if you're not careful. Each enemy has unique attack patterns and since you only have melee attack at the beginning of the game, you have to do your best to hit the enemy while dodging their attacks that are indicated by red marks.

Enemies have a lot of variants of the same type. A higher variant will sometimes drop an egg that you can hatch and keep as your pet. There are also evolved variants that will drop some essences that you can use to evolve your pet. However, I found that the egg drop rate is very low, especially in the latter part of the game.

[b]Equipment[/b]
You can only level up by switching gear. However, crafting gears are RNG-based; there are different qualities and bonus stats that will only be revealed after you craft them. Saving and loading become vital if you don't want to gather the resources again to get the best gear.

The game also has other items called gadgets and devices that you can place in your hotkey to use. These items have different effects - from hitting the enemy from a long distance to making you invulnerable for a few seconds. However, I found that there were too many of them and most of them were useless since you only need to get ranged items to kill end game enemies. I never bothered to test new items after I filled all of my hotkeys with the ranged ones.

[b]Bosses[/b]
The game has 11 bosses with different attack patterns and element types. You also can't outgear the bosses in the hardest difficulty so you need to learn the attack pattern properly to finish the fight. Since it's risky to melee most bosses, I found that I ended up hitting all bosses with items in my hotkey slots from afar until they die. However, sometimes the auto-lock loses its target that I had to spam click on the bosses whenever I could to make sure that I didn't lose the target.

[b]Difficulty[/b]
The game offers 4 difficulties that you can choose before you start the game. I played the game in the hardest difficulty and I didn't have any problem with it. The monsters take a long time to kill though; it might even take minutes to kill a stronger monster than your level. You also can die in 1 hit by an enemy that is weaker than you.

[b]Length[/b]
It took me 55h to finish the game in story mode and an extra 4h to obtain all of the grindy achievements. The rest of my playtime is spent in finishing hardcore mode, which might take longer or faster based on your skill.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's a game where you can do a lot of things to craft and kill enemies. The game has a lot of unique bosses and vast maps to explore.

I've been jonesing for a decent survival game for a while, and I will say this one hits the spot. Others have compared it to Don't Starve and gameplay-wise, I suppose it could be like that a little. You play Flux, a space trucker whose ship was destroyed by a sinister floating head. To get back at the floating head and get off the planet you're stranded on, you'll have to gather resources and help out the natives in what is very clearly a comedic romp through an alien world.

I never enjoyed Don't Starve because of its soul-crushing difficulty, and I wasn't readily attracted to a game with similar playstyle, but Butterscotch Shenanigans does a great job with their trailers, and since it was on sale for $5, I decided to give it a try. Mainly, I've been sold on the fact that I don't feel punished for simply wandering around aimlessly, smashing resources and treasure chests along the way. Your inventory is limitless, but craftable items can often cost a lot of resources, so plan to chop at everything you run across on the inevitable chance that you'll need it to craft something later.

Pets can be earned and upgraded to be more effective in combat. I love the Pokemon reference in-game when they're evolved. Enemies also don't seem to target pets, which can be a double-edged sword if yours does AoE (Are of Effect) damage, pulling an entire herd of Wompits down on your head.

Crafting recipes are unlocked through quests and harvesting resources. It's always exciting to work your way through a forest only to have a random logtree drop a new recipe. There are also teleporters EVERYWHERE. Alongside the infinite inventory, this is one of my favorite features. It's annoying to have to jog back and forth between your home and whatever wilderness you were in because you need to craft more health potions.

It might sound like a casual experience, but it definitely has its challenges. I've died five times as of the writing of this review, mostly due to underestimating the power of the enemies. But death doesn't feel soul-crushing--it feels like a lesson learned. If a herd of Wompits stomps you into a bloody pool, maybe don't take on a whole herd next time.

There are definitely some areas where I think the game could be improved, though. Enemies spawn in thick clusters which can quickly overwhelm you when you meant to only fight one or two at a time. You earn perks in-game and I've earned a few, but I couldn't even tell you what they are because they go by the screen so fast, and there's no obvious way to review them afterwards. The data screen is also severely lacking, and I want to go a bit more into that.

With an infinite inventory, there is no place where you can quickly review the items you have. For example, if I am trying to make sure I have enough sticks to make something that requires them, I either need to have that item already on my tracker (which can only track one recipe at a time, BTW), or go all the way back home and check the recipe in the crafting station. It would have been nice to have this feature in the data panel, along with the list of perks unlocked, and maybe even a catalog of unlocked recipes. Anything to reduce the amount of unnecessary trips to my home base.

Anyway, that doesn't stop me from playing and enjoying the game. Flux has a jaunty little skip while she roams the land chopping up the baddies and harvesting their parts for equipment. Her back and forth with the NPCs can also be really funny at times. I recommend it for anyone who likes exploring, active combat, and collecting things in their games, with a dash of humor to top it off.

[b]**[u] Key was provided by developer for review purposes	[/u]**[/b]
[b]Review will continue to be updated as I play through the game[/b] 

[h1]Crashlands [/h1] 

Crashlands is a humorous and well-done large world RPG set on an alien landscape. Combing elements of survival, story, and humor to create an amazing title. I will add a TL;DR at the end.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1] 

You are Flux and you are handling a urgent delivery with your robotic companion Juicebox. Your ship is destroyed by quite the purple head thingy... yeah.  You are now stranded on an alien planet and have to try and establish communication again and survive on the planet with its hostile environment.

The controls within this game are fairly simple using the mouse to either click and you will move there or hold it and you character will move where your mouse is. Crashlands also utilizes the A S D F and C V buttons as quick buttons, the A S D F buttons can be changed to quickly use your items while the C and V buttons are for your wonderfully murderous pet. The game mechanic is done well and I can see how easily it is converted to its mobile counterpart. Crashlands has a large amount of customizable floors and walls with useless furniture to behold. The game does a nice job of guiding you through everything and learning the game with rather comedic moments with Flux and Juicebox whether it be between themselves or the non-hostile inhabitants of the planet. The combat mechanic in the game is very fun as it requires you to be intelligent about you approach with every creature you see, which wants to kill you.... which is almost the entire planet. This game also removes the hassle of having to manage you inventory because apparently you have black hole pockets, just don't question it and be happy. Other than the expected do quest, get gear, and farm stuff mechanics you would expect of an RPG you can also rip the eggs from the creatures you kill and then raise their baby to murder their past brethren, overall very nice as long as you don't think too much on how STWOMPY (My personal Wombit) killed over 100 of his own kind already along with other creatures (so proud). The only problem is having to go back to old areas to remove bits of black so I can see the whole map, as it's quite the long process.

[h1]Graphics/Sounds[/h1] 

The graphics are cartoonish and more innocent than anything else. They are polished and very smooth and the evolution screen while you evolve your pet is quite majestic to watch. The music is alright and the sounds match the creature well.

[h1]Pros/Cons [/h1] 

[b]Pros [/b] 

+ Great survival element
+ Good amount of customization
+ Large game allowing you to play for hours on end 
+ Cross-platform saves

[b]Cons [/b] 

- Annoying to have to go back to previous areas of the map to fill it out without black areas
- Moments where a crafting recipe I was tracking is replaced by a quest item track when I talk for the quest (slightly annoying, perhaps an option to not automatically change the tracked recipe?)
- Grinding is existent and prevalent within the game

[h1]Suggestions [/h1] 

These are my personal suggestions that I feel would improve the game.

- With the editor major update (when it is released) there should be an option to create custom player models and creature models to help create a true sense of freedom through customization in the update. 
- If the created creature is hostile the ability to select its attack patten would be amazing
- Workshop for maps and mods with the large scale update
- Ability to have "Vanity items" meaning that you could be waring one item for stats, but you can use another item that you prefer visually to be seen on you
- Ability to see pet stats. To be able to see stats such as growth (Ex 26/100 and when it is evolved #/300), damage, and unique attack chance.
- Future Co-op feature 

[h1]Final thoughts [/h1] 

I played Don't Starve and it was nice, but it wasn't my cup of tea. Crashlands however dragged me in and keeps me there. The game is fun and even though it is meant more for a mobile platform with its control scheme it does not take away from its value as a game in itself. It's a challenging game and makes you a bit more alert as you try not to get stomped out of existence. I love Flux and her attitude along with Juicebox and I think this game is something I could easily recommend to those who like Don't Starve but want something different and a bit more lighthearted. Also the trailer is just perfect.

[h1]TL;DR [/h1] 

The game is a more lighthearted version of Don't Starve and is able to keep you in a way Don't Starve couldn't. The game has mobile controls but it really doesn't hurt the game as a whole. There is a large amount of customization and the RPG element is great. This allows for the game to be a large, more open world, RPG survival game. It's actually cool that the main character is a female and the interactions she has between the non-hostile inhabitants of the alien planet, or her robotic companion Juicebox are very humorous at points. There are not many issues I am able to find as I play through the game. The only issues I see people having is that there is a grinding element to the game and that there are times on the map where you have to move to previous areas to have a fully exposed map without any black spots. I would definitely recommend this to people who want a different take on the Don't Starve survival technique or simply want to try something new and love an RPG element with customization.

21473190.review:
[b]Don't be fooled by the playtime, I've logged tens of hours on Android for this game.[/b]

[h1]TL:DR You'd be hard pressed to find a game as rewarding and well-made as this one. [/h1]

[b]There's crafting, survival, cooking, fishing, building, questing, and plenty else to do in this game. Crashlands is REALLY good, and each of its mechanics is so well done, you'll wonder why other developers hadn't thought to do it this way.[/b]

For the full review, I'm going to break things down by mechanics and features. New players will also be able to learn some useful tips about the game, by reading this.

So, let's start with:

[b]Storyline and Gameplay[/b]

For starters, this game is pretty funny. It doesn't take itself seriously, and has jokes and humour littered througout. The thing is, it's all quite well done, and creates an enjoyable world to explore and discover. The characters you'll meet are often silly and entertaining, but not in any way that breaks immersion. Overall, it's very well done, and by doing the storyline quests and side quests, you unlock more recipes and ingredients to use to make your character even stronger. 

[b]Crafting[/b]

The crafting system in the game is very well done. There are different crafting stations for different tiers of equipment and tools. There are a lot of similarities between this system and Starbound, however this one ups that by offering ideas that make it easier to craft. One of my favourite features of crafting is the ability to track a recipe. Click "Track" then you'll see what ingredients you'll need to craft that item. As you collect the ingredients, you'll see how much you have, and how much you still need, in order to make that item. 

Recipes are another fun aspect of the game as you start with a bunch when you make a new station. You can also get new recipes from finishing quests. My favourite feature, however, is that you can get epic and legendary recipes from resource drops, mob drops, and fishing. It's very rewarding to kill an enemy and suddenly see a recipe box pop out. It could be anything from a new piece of furnature for your house to a legendary blueprint for a piece of equipment. 

Crafting is this games' killer app, and it really is killer.

[b]Exploration and Map[/b]

Exploration in Crashlands is very similar to Don't Starve. You start at your pod, and as you travel further out, your map gets filled in, block by block. 
The further away you get, the more interesting (read:dreadly) the enemies become. Then again, the greater the risk, the greater the reward. There are lots of interesting places to discover, and NPC locations are littered everywhere, which results in gaining new quests, learning more about the planet you've crashed on, and of course, more recipes and lot. 

It also helps that the art style in Crashlands is wonderfully colourful, with lots of glowy things that light up the world in a myriad of colours. Exploration is FUN FUN FUN in Crashlands.

[b]Cooking and Fishing[/b]

At a certain point in the game, you're going to gain access to a hearth for cooking, and later, a fishing rod for fishing. 

Unlike a lot of games that have fishing spots randomly appear in different places, fishing spots are permanent in Crashlands. That means you can place signs (assuming you've crafted some) at any spots you find, and come back to them every two hours. At one point, I was using signs to label sites on the map, but eventually the game one upped that by giving me a recipe for an item that creates fishing spots in any body of water I choose. 

Let me remind you, fishing spots are pemanent, so these items were a Godsend, as fishing is not only very rewarding, it's also very enjoyable. Add to that the fact that you can also gain legendary items and recipes from fishing, and you have a system that will keep you coming back for more. 

Fishing spot cooldowns will continue to count down, even when you're not playing the game, so long as you haven't left the game paused. Pausing the game and leaving it, unfortunately, also pauses timers. Bummer for sure, but this can be avoided by simply exiting the game when you walk away from it. The game saves everything automatically, so you won't lose anything by doing so.

As for cooking, when you use the hearth, you'll have a bunch of recipes for potions. Potions provide health, speed, resistences, etc. There are all sorts of boosts and benefits from potions, so you'll want to pursue that, when the hearth comes available. 

Quick tip: There's a quest, not long after you get the hearth, that'll allow you to make really good health potions out of fish and stone. If you have a rod and a hearth, but not this recipe? Do some quests, it's worth it... so worth it.

[b]Building[/b]

Building is another great feature in this game. It's extremely simple to get some building supplies, then activate build mode which will allow you to click (or tap) anywhere on the screen to place that item. 
Additionally, each building type is seperated into function. Floors have their own section, so it's easy to select that item set, choose a floor type, and just start pasting those floor tiles down the way you want. 
Vegetation (farming... yes, this game TOTALLY has farming) is another section, and you can plant your seeds, and place potted plants which can both be harvested after a 15 minute cooldown. 

Again, cooldowns will continue to count down while you're out of the game, so be sure to check back on your farms, from time to time. 

[b]Animal Taming[/b]

Here is perhaps one of my favourite features of Crashlands, you can have pets! Pets serve two features. First, you can feed your pets to harvest resources from them. These resources can be used in certain recipes, and often come in really handy. 
The second function, and perhaps the most important, you can take one of your pets out with you while you explore. They'll fight for you, while they keep you company. Additionally, they're invincible, so you don't need to worry about them getting killed by other baddies. They also don't need to be fed to stay aline, feeding is only something you do when you want to... milk them... 

How about one more awesome point of keeping animals... Well, you can also unlock recipes for items that will cause your animals to permanently evolve into larger and more powerful versions. Each animal has multiple stages of growth, each one making them bigger, stronger, and look cooler, each time. 

You should get an egg drop for each enemy type, shortly after you've crafted a station that can make that animal's nest. 

Keeping animals is absolutely worth it, in this game.

[b]Looting and Inventory[/b]

There's loot... lots and lots of loot. When you kill creatures, fish, harvest resources, etc, you'll get showerd with items and materials. The key point here is that there is not traditional inventory with a sprawling list of things you have and don't have. The inventory system manages all of that for you, and there is NO LIMIT TO INVENTORY SPACE. As you pick things up, they will scroll by discreetly on the left, along with a number in brackets which indicates how many you have in total. 

The inventory system in Crashlands is another one of those features that makes you wonder why it has taken so long for a developer to think of it. It's clean, efficient, simple to figure out, and cuts out all the mess of traditional inventory spaces.

As mentioned before, all enemies, resource points, and fishing have a chance of dropping some epic items, so there will be a lot of "OMG That's AWESOME" moments in your adventures with Crashlands. 

[b]Summary[/b]

Seems I'm at the word limit for this review, so let me just sum it up by saying, Crashlands is one hell of a good game. It aces its presentation, mechanics, sense of rewarding, and enjoyment. If you haven't purchased it yet, do yourself a favour and get in on the fun.

You go out and gather the required ingredients from dead enemies and the environment, come back, make your armour and weapons, and you're now a bit stronger. If you remake them, you have a chance of getting a better version (common, uncommon, rare etc.) with better stats, so re-making items can be worthwhile if you have the resources spare. Eventually, you make your next Bench, and the cycle continues all over again.

You also have missions. Lots of missions. It's virtually impossible to explore the whole world unless you really really don't have anything better to do. It's huge. Answer: Not very

What we have here is the aim to take out everthing tedious from world-sprawling RPG's... and just make them all about [i]fun[/i]. So the guys blasphemously ripped out many of staples we're sick of... Letting us focus on the important things: Beating up the local wildlife and collecting stuff to make bigger stuff to beat up bigger local wildlife. So we no longer have to manage an unweildy inventory and angrily raid about 50 chests for that 1 item we know we picked up somewhere, but likely left in an outpost in God-knows-where (yay). The map is littered with teleporters that let us hop around the place on a whim (yay). And if you die, you can just go back, pick up your stuff and carry on (yay)

On the surface, this might seem worrying. By removing all this, does it leave a rather shallow game? Not really. What it ultimately does is make it exceptionally approachable and give you the freedom to muck about and just... enjoy it. Seriously, I could just mill about the Savannah for ages - it was just so relaxing. That's not to say it's easy (you will die... a lot), but it's laid back and easy to dip into.

The only real weak point is the armour crafting. Basically, your kit will randomly have special effects when you craft them (poisoning, going berserk, resisting damage...) - but it cannot be carried over when you upgrade. This sucks big time, as you'll repeatedly end up with Excellent Level kit... then have to forge like 30 items of the next level in the hope that one of them will actually have bonuses worth upgrading to. And you're forced to upgrade A LOT (the enemies scale quite dramatically). It ironically adds a lot of tedium to a game hell-bent on removing it. It's frustrating and can detract from the enjoyment - but there is at least enough enjoyment to be had to mitigate it to a degree.

Other than that though, it's great fun! The combat is reminiscent of the old Mega Drive platformers: Studying the attack patterns and finding the sequences to best get a hit in. It's one of those games that make you wish that Steam had a more complex grading system rather than the binary one. Crashlands is a game that reminds many (including myself) of Don't Starve. In my opinion it is to Don't Starve, what American remakes are to European original films. It's goofier and more flashy, but in the process loses the idea of what makes the original so genius.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Crashlands drops you into an alien world, where you need to craft and help the locals to retrieve the packages lost during the crash landing. You have to scavenge and hunt mobs for materials that allow you to craft better gear and challenge harder mobs. It's actually fun for the first few hours, until you notice, this is it, that's basically the whole game. Just grind to craft another workstation, another weapon, another armour. It might have been okay as one of the possible activities, but it gets really old when it's the only activity available. And you have to do it a lot. There are 35 levels of equipment and they increment in twos. This means, the same gameplay loop has to be repeated around 17 times, that's at least 10 times too many. It's also possible to 'domesticate' pets, until you notice, that it's basically another part of the crafting system as the domesticated pets create materials which you'll need to create your weapons and armours with. It doesn't really help that the design of most of the gear is rather uninspiring. You can have the same sword/axe/helmet/etc. every 2 levels. I mean, it looks different, but the only actual difference is that it deals a bit more damage than the same item of the lower tier and a bit less damage than the item of the next tier. Only the gadgets and devices are a small breath of fresh air, at least some of them offer interesting, new mechanics.

Another gameplay element that's gravely underdeveloped is base building. There are possibilities of building furniture, plants and some other random stuff, but they (mostly) serve no purpose. You can just put them around if you feel like it, but there isn't really any good reason to do so. The only things that are actually needed are workstations, which allow you to craft better and better gear (there's like 20 of them) and pets nest. The rest of furniture might as well not exist.

The enemies are nicely designed in terms of their looks and attack patterns, however, they all suffer from one major problem - bullet sponging. Most of the time you'll find yourself slapping the enemies with your ineffective weapon for mediocre damage and just running around to not get hit. When you get better weapons, you'll move on to other enemies which will have the same spongey feeling to them. On the other hand enemies attacks welcome you to the world of hurt. Most special enemies will deal enough damage to one-shot you. There are many defensive stats, but at some point you'll probably notice, that the most important one is indeed the HP, that lets you survive the one hit and quickly heal up, the rest probably matters, but there isn't any in-game explanation of what do they exactly do. Like what does 20% toughness do? Does it decrease the physical damage by 20%? More? Less? Does it mean 100% toughness makes you invulnerable to physical damage? Who knows...

Enemies' attacks usually give you a lot of time to dodge, but it's unfortunately balanced with the speed your character is moving. By far one of the most frustrating things about Crashlands is the fact that most of the time you're literally crawling through the world. Being able to activate the 'turbo mode' helps a bit, but you can't have 100% uptime on it, so that sucks. Something like a Don't Starve's 'Walking stick' would be a great help to the game - that is an item that allows you to walk really fast outside of combat, but has to be switched to a weapon during combat, so it would still not be that easy to dodge the attacks.

There are also some minor bugs in the game, where quests aren't properly marked on the map or your teleporting doesn't work the first time you click (happens A LOT). Not that big of a deal in the end, but it does show the lack of polish of the game.

[h1] Story and Quests [/h1]

The story initially got me interested. It was a bit goofy, a bit crazy but it held up. I was following it rather closely until the end of Savannah, the first act. After that though, I was a bit underwhelmed with the game mechanics and just felt like finishing it up for the sake of being done with it, reading just a part here and there to still know what's going on. Reaching the last level, Tundra, I was so worn out I would just skip every dialogue ASAP. It didn't matter anyway and it did feel stretched just for the sake of having three acts.

This might have been different if the quests were a bit more creative, but unfortunately they aren't. 90% of the quests will be your typical 'kill this/gather that/talk to someone'. As I mentioned before, it might be interesting enough for the first act, but after that you'll find just skipping most of the dialogues and then checking your quests screen for the item that you actually need to gather up to finish the quest.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

For me the strongest asset of this game. Crashlands looks neat. It's colourful and it feels alive. Even though most of your gear does the same, it looks differently, based on the materials that were used in the crafting process. The enemies and allies look a bit (positively) weird, which fits the goofy, alien theme of the game. The animations are fluid, damage indicators clear and you can easily spot all the materials as they have their distinctive looks.

My only complaint here would be the lack of possibility (at least I haven't found it) to disable screenshake. I always turn it off in any game I play, and I found it as annoying in Crashlands as in any other game.

[h1] Sound and Music [/h1]

I actually liked the music of the game of the game and I think I had it on for most part of the game. It was nothing to write home about, but it also didn't get on my nerves, which is important, as the game is about 30 hours long and you'll be hearing lots of it on repeat.

The sounds were mostly well chosen. Enemy sounds were fitting, 'juicy' sounds were 'juicy' enough. No complaints there.

On the other hand, the person who decided to put the 'thumping' tree in the game, should really re-evaluate how it impacts the playthrough. Hearing that annoying sound for 'roughly' the 8 hours you spend in the last act was stuff of nightmares.

[h1] Overall [/h1]

Crashlands does some things good, it does most things mediocre and a few things - plain bad. It is even a great game up until the point where you notice you've basically seen everything and still have around 20 hours of grind left. If it took 10 hours to complete, this review would probably even be a positive one. It's just, that the game is stretched to almost 30 hours, but the content is just not there anymore past the first act. I mean, you'll see new monsters and the story progresses, but it doesn't feel different enough to justify it.

If I were to describe Crashlands in one word it would be 'uninspired'. The gameplay design just doesn't change one thing and you simply can't have players doing the same for almost 30 hours, it's boring and frankly, quite tiring. The only thing I could think of after I've beaten the final boss was the LoTR's 'It's over, it's done', I was happy to finally finish it and I know, I won't be coming back.

24575784.review:
Before I knew it five hours had passed is I think all I need to say about this game.

To be more specific though... it kind of feels like it reinvents the wheel when it comes to crafting/building RPG games. In a good way. There's very little in the way of tedious wait times when things are crafting and the recipes are usually simple enough not to have a whole ton of things you need to build to build things you need to build things with. If that makes sense. It's fast in other words so you can get back to smashing things.

Combat is slightly more complicated than it seems with each enemy having unique attack patterns that you need to learn to avoid. However realistically I found that since most of the big enemies could kill me outright in one or two hits dancing around them trying to get hits in is just too risky most of the time. Even a small enemy attacks so fast they can catch you off guard or between healing item cooldowns and wipe you out.

The best option seems to be to just aggro as much stuff as possible with ranged attacks and let your trusty one legged rhino-cow-thing AOE stomp everything into oblivion whilst you carry on mining stuff or chopping wood whilst dodging attacks. This is pretty hilarious to watch and somehow never really gets old. The only problem is said trusty rhino-cow isn't so trusty as to continue attacking the swarm of cosmic monstrosities following you unless you keep throwing in the odd ranged attack to keep his interest. If he kills his target he'll just run back to you and ignore the other dozen critters until you attack something too. I feel this was done deliberately to stop easy farming by just letting the pet do all the work but it can make things awkward as it is often near impossible to actually get an attack in whilst giant land-squids, butterflys and rhinos are doing their best to separate your brains from your skull.

One big issue I continually had is the pathfinding. Click to move games are never my favourite but after a few minutes of instinctively trying to WASD my way around the place I had become quite comfortable with it. Until I clicked inside the house only for my character to run headfirst into a wall for ten seconds. Try to cross any land dotted with water and it's even worse requiring constant clicks right in front of you just to keep him from trying to drown himself. This can be even more awkward in combat when you try to use a ranged attack only for him to run directly into melee range because there just happened to be a small bush blocking the shot. In a game with mouse only control the pathfinding really could do with being a bit better than this.

Having WASD as the item bar seems like a clever middle finger to traditional keyboard controls however having access to just four items can be a little limited and detrimental to the game. Two of those slots have to be taken by the wrench and blowpipe ranged weapons for practicality and the other two have to be taken by the basic food items at the moment since the cooldown is so high on them and the amount they heal so low. All the nice bomb recipes I've found are too dangerous to use until I get better healing items. I found a recipe for a HP potion but it is quite costly and currently heals more health than I actually have... and presumably will also be on a 30 second cooldown.

That said there isn't really any penalty to dying, true to the quick paced nature of the game. You can just teleport immediately after respawning to a nearby portal and are rarely more than 30 seconds away from recovering all your stuff. Whilst it may seem a little weird to totally remove any fear of death like this it really just serves to make the game more enjoyable. I can't count the amount of times in Terraria, Minecraft or similar that I've spent an hour grinding resources only to get killed by something stupid and rush back as quickly as possible to get my gear only to find it gone. In at least half of those innumerous situations I've just quit the game and got bored of it for the day.

The infinite inventory and lack of hours spent sorting through chests and juggling resources around also serves well to focus this game on actual gameplay and not a shelf stacking simulator. All of these things make it feel like a far more casual and basic game but they also make it more about action. The game is also pretty funny with great dialogue however it does concern me that it is very linear so far so I don't know that it will have anywhere near as much replay value as similar games. That said, after five hours I don't appear to have even glimpsed the end so all in all it is well worth the £10.
